error.signature: error NETSDK1045: The current .NET SDK does not support targeting .NET 8.0. Either target .NET 7.0 or lower, or use a version of the .NET SDK that supports .NET 8.0.

verdict.summary: SDK version mismatch build failures occur when the installed .NET SDK does not support the target framework specified in the project. Caused by global.json pinning to an unavailable SDK version, outdated SDK installations, or CI environments with the wrong SDK. Fix by installing the correct SDK version or updating global.json.

dead_ends.action: Downgrading the target framework in .csproj to match an older installed SDK
dead_ends.why_fails: Changes the application's target framework, potentially breaking API usage and removing access to newer features. Other developers and CI systems still need the correct SDK, so this only fixes the local machine

dead_ends.action: Deleting global.json to use whatever SDK is installed
dead_ends.why_fails: global.json exists to ensure consistent builds across environments; removing it causes different developers to build with different SDK versions, leading to subtle behavioral differences and 'works on my machine' problems

workarounds.action: Install the correct .NET SDK version specified in global.json or required by the project
workarounds.how: Check the required version: cat global.json or look at <TargetFramework> in .csproj. Download and install from https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download or use the dotnet-install script: curl -sSL https://dot.net/v1/dotnet-install.sh | bash /dev/stdin --version 8.0.xxx. Verify with 'dotnet --list-sdks'

workarounds.action: Update global.json to use rollForward policy
workarounds.how: Edit global.json to add a rollForward policy that allows newer patch or feature band versions: { "sdk": { "version": "8.0.100", "rollForward": "latestFeature" } }. The 'latestFeature' policy allows any 8.0.xxx SDK, while 'latestPatch' restricts to 8.0.1xx patches only

leads_to.condition: when SDK mismatch causes NuGet to fail resolving framework-specific packages
when different SDK versions resolve different implicit package versions
when partial build produces missing assembly references

preceded_by.condition: when Dockerfile uses a base image with a different SDK version than expected
when investigating restore failures reveals the underlying SDK version problem

frequently_confused_with.distinction: SDK mismatch is about the .NET SDK version being incompatible with the target framework; NuGet restore failure is about packages not being found or downloaded from package sources
